text:
This tune represents the game as whole well to me, in that it conveys solace, loneliness, solitude.
A peculiar example, albeit not my first, in that I think it's a good tune, yet dislike it for how depressing it sounds to me.

text: This game is definitely a LOT tougher than the first but I'm really enjoying it.. I have learnt that my souls are incredibly hard to keep and this was noticeable when in the Lost Bastille, all the knights just charge at you as soon as you entered the doorway and instead of bursting into tears, I just burst into laughter at how screwed I was.
author: Theo Cann

text: I'm about four hours into the PS3 version SupraDarky—I won't spoil anything, but you have nothing to fear. At least so far, Dark Souls 2 is just as good as the first, and probably better. I love it. Can't wait to play more later after work. :)

text: Hey Supra I love your channel!  If you have not checked it out already, I urge you to check out the soundtrack to Desktop Dungeons.  It is a collaboration between Grant Kirkhope (N64 Rare Composer) and Danny Baranowsky (Super meat boy, Binding of  Isaac) and it has some great tracks!  Cheers!

text: I'm sure it's a great song, but I'm going to be listening to this for the first time in-game!  The minimalist style of the souls series means there's not much musically, so I'm going to let the song speak to me then.  Needless to say, this is one of my most anticipated games in quite some time.

text:
This is probably the only thing I'll get out of the game in a long while...

author: Sire Red

text: With the Souls series being one my favorites of all time, Dark Souls II has been my most anticipated release since its reveal. I'll be playing the PC version this time, now that I have a powerful computer. Majula is this game's hub, it gives me Demon's Souls vibes mixed with Sakuraba's style (especially the harp). It's a peaceful theme, but you know you'll be in for some serious trouble as soon as you step out of the hub.
